ground_truth: The two sisters walk away from the rack, Hannah slightly in the lead. Holly pauses, looking at her sister. They continue to walk. Holly looks at her sister for a beat. A female customer, who'd come over to the table, browsing through the rack of clothes near Hannah, looks up, reacting. She walks away. She walks past Holly and briefly looks at a different rack of clothes beneath the table. She walks offscreen to a nearby rack; the camera remains focused on Holly. Holly chuckles and begins to look through the scarves on the table. A group of theater executives, including the producer, the director, and two assistants, sit in a cluster in the empty audience, talking; they look up at the offscreen Holly, who is auditioning on the stage. The film moves from the audience to the stage where Holly, her hands clasped in front of her, continues to sing her song. A large group of other hopefuls are seen in the background behind her. The camera moves from Holly back to the executives in the audience. The camera has reached the executives in the audience. They are now chattering among themselves, Holly forgotten. A theater marquee can be seen on the busy street as Holly and April walk down the street towards the camera, moving closer and closer as they talk. Holly looks away sadly; she shakes her head. The film cuts to Father Flynn's rectory office. The Catholic priest looks out a simple stained-glass window, then turns to an offscreen Mickey. The camera moves back to reveal Mickey, his back to the camera, sitting in front of Father Flynn's desk. The movie cuts to Mickey's face. The camera cuts back to Father Flynn, who walks over to a leather armchair next to a table set for tea. He begins to pour the tea into china cups. Father Flynn clasps his hands in his lap. The film abruptly cuts to the long hallway in Mickey's parents' apartment. Mickey's mother stands in front of this bureau at the hallway's end, screaming at the top of her lungs, holding her heart dramatically. His father walks into view, carrying a teacup and a candy dish. He strides past Mickey towards the kitchen. Holding the dirty dishes in his hand, Mickey's father looks at his son. Mickey's father walks offscreen again, to the kitchen sink. Mickey's father walks out of the kitchen, past his son, to the living room. Mickey stops at the bathroom door at the other end of the hallway. He starts to pound it. Mickey's father comes back on screen; he's carrying a plate of hors d'oeuvres and an empty glass towards the kitchen. He stops and looks down the hall at Mickey, who's now struggling to open the bathroom door.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution

Holly gazes at her sibling for an instant. A woman patron, who'd arrived over to the table, perusing through the stand of garments adjacent to Hannah, glances up, responding. She strolls away. She strides past Holly and fleetingly glances at a separate stand of garments underneath the table. She strolls offscreen to a nearby stand; the camera remains concentrated on Holly. Holly giggles and starts to peruse through the scarves on the table. The film transitions from the spectators to the stage where Holly, her hands clasped in front of her, continues to sing her melody. Holly glances away sadly; she shakes her head. The film transitions to Father Flynn's rectory office. The Catholic clergyman gazes out a simple stained-glass window, then turns to an offscreen Mickey. The camera transitions back to reveal Mickey, his back to the camera, seated in front of Father Flynn's desk. The movie transitions to Mickey's visage. The camera transitions back to Father Flynn, who strides over to a leather armchair adjacent to a table arranged for tea. He starts to pour the tea into china cups. Father Flynn clasps his hands in his lap. The film abruptly transitions to the long corridor in Mickey's parents' apartment. Mickey's mother stands in front of this dresser at the corridor's end, shrieking at the top of her lungs, clutching her heart dramatically. His father strides into view, bearing a teacup and a candy dish. He strides past Mickey towards the kitchen. Holding the soiled dishes in his hand, Mickey's father glances at his offspring. Mickey's father strides offscreen again, to the kitchen sink. Mickey's father strides out of the kitchen, past his offspring, to the living room. Mickey pauses at the bathroom door at the opposite end of the corridor. He starts to pound it. Mickey's father returns on screen; he's bearing a plate of hors d'oeuvres and an empty glass towards the kitchen. He pauses and glances down the corridor at Mickey, who's now struggling to open the bathroom door.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The rack is walked away from by the two sisters, Hannah slightly in the lead. Holly pauses, her sister is looked at by her. The walk is continued by them. Her sister is looked at by Holly for a beat. A female customer, who'd come over to the table, browses through the rack of clothes near Hannah, looks up and reacts. She is walked away by her. Holly is walked past by her and a different rack of clothes beneath the table is briefly looked at by her. A nearby rack is walked offscreen to by her; Holly is focused on by the camera. Holly chuckles and the scarves on the table are begun to be looked through by her. A group of theater executives, including the producer, the director, and two assistants, sit in a cluster in the empty audience, talking; they look up at Holly, who auditions on the stage. The film moves from the audience to the stage where Holly, her hands clasped in front of her, continues to sing her song. A large group of other hopefuls sees her in the background behind her. The camera moves from Holly back to the executives in the audience. The executives in the audience are reached by the camera. Chattering among themselves is done by them, Holly forgotten. A theater marquee is seen on the busy street as Holly and April walk down the street towards the camera, moving closer and closer as they talk. Away is looked by Holly sadly; her head is shaken by her. The film cuts to Father Flynn's rectory office. Out a simple stained-glass window looks the Catholic priest, then turns to Mickey, who is offscreen. The camera moves back to reveal Mickey, sitting in front of Father Flynn's desk with his back to the camera. The movie cuts to Mickey's face. Back is cut to Father Flynn by the camera, who walks over to a leather armchair next to a table set for tea. Tea is begun to be poured by him into china cups. His hands are clasped in his lap by Father Flynn. The film abruptly cuts to the long hallway in Mickey's parents' apartment. In front of this bureau at the hallway's end, Mickey's mother stands, screaming at the top of her lungs, holding her heart dramatically. Mickey's father walks into view, carrying a teacup and a candy dish. Mickey is walked past by him towards the kitchen. Holding the dirty dishes in his hand, his son is looked at by Mickey's father. Offscreen again, to the kitchen sink walks Mickey's father. Out of the kitchen walks Mickey's father, past his son, to the living room. At the bathroom door at the other end of the hallway, Mickey stops. He starts pounding it. Mickey's father comes back on screen; a plate of hors d'oeuvres and an empty glass are carried by him towards the kitchen. He stops and looks down the hall at Mickey, the bathroom door now struggling to be opened by him.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The two sisters walk away from the rack, with Hannah slightly ahead. Holly pauses, gazing at her sister, then continues. A female customer browsing near Hannah reacts and walks past Holly, briefly glancing at another rack beneath the table before leaving. Holly chuckles and examines the scarves. A group of theater executives, including the producer and director, sit talking in the audience. They look up at offscreen Holly, who's auditioning on stage, singing with hopefuls behind her. The camera shifts between Holly and the distracted executives. Holly and April stroll down a busy street toward the camera; Holly looks away sadly and shakes her head. The scene cuts to Father Flynn's rectory, where he looks out a stained-glass window, then turns to Mickey, seated with his back to the camera. The camera reveals Mickey's face, then Father Flynn pours tea, clasping his hands. It abruptly shifts to Mickey's parents' hallway, where his mother screams dramatically, holding her heart. His father carries a teacup, strides past Mickey to the kitchen, then returns with hors d'oeuvres, watching Mickey struggling to open the bathroom door.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Hannah leads as the sisters walk away from the rack. Holly pauses, watching her sister. A female customer near Hannah reacts, then moves past Holly to browse another rack, leaving the camera on Holly. Holly chuckles and examines scarves. In a theater, a producer, director, and assistants sit in the audience watching Holly audition on stage, singing with hopefuls behind her. They soon forget Holly as they chatter. On a busy street, Holly and April walk toward the camera. Holly looks away sadly, shaking her head. The scene shifts to Father Flynn’s office, where he looks out a stained-glass window at Mickey, then pours tea. The film cuts to Mickey's parents’ apartment. His mother dramatically screams, holding her heart, as his father walks past Mickey to the kitchen with dishes. Mickey pounds on the bathroom door, and his father, with snacks and an empty glass, pauses to look at him.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
The two sisters, moving together yet with Hannah slightly ahead, begin to walk away from the clothing rack. As they proceed, Holly pauses momentarily, casting a thoughtful glance at her sister. They continue their walk, maintaining their sisterly pace. Holly takes another lingering look at her sister, pondering momentarily. Meanwhile, a female customer, who had approached the table, is browsing through the rack of clothes situated near Hannah and suddenly lifts her gaze in reaction. This customer then decides to walk away. She strolls past Holly, briefly casting her eyes on a different rack of clothes positioned beneath the table. Her journey continues as she walks offscreen toward a nearby rack, while the camera's focus remains steadfastly on Holly. With a chuckle, Holly starts to sift through the selection of scarves adorning the table. 

In the theater, a group comprising several theater executives, including the influential producer, the creative director, and two diligent assistants, is seated in a closely-knit cluster amidst the empty audience seats. They are engaged in conversation, but soon they look up, directing their attention towards Holly, who is performing offscreen, auditioning on the stage. As the film transitions from the audience to the stage, Holly is revealed to be standing there, her hands elegantly clasped in front of her as she continues to sing her song with passion. A large group of other aspiring performers can be seen waiting patiently in the background behind her, creating an atmosphere of hopeful anticipation. The camera's angle shifts from Holly back to the executives seated in the audience. Once the camera reaches them, they are now animatedly chattering among themselves, seemingly having already forgotten about Holly in the midst of their conversation.

The scene shifts to a bustling street where a theater marquee is visible. Holly, accompanied by April, walks along the street, moving closer and closer to the camera as they engage in conversation. A hint of sadness crosses Holly's face as she looks away, her expression marked by a slow shake of her head. The film then cuts to the serene interior of Father Flynn's rectory office. The Catholic priest stands gazing out of a simply adorned stained-glass window before turning his attention to someone offscreen, Mickey. The camera angle adjusts, gradually revealing Mickey, who is positioned with his back to the camera, sitting in a chair facing Father Flynn's imposing desk. The scene transitions to capture Mickey's face, and then the camera reverts back to Father Flynn, who moves over to a nearby leather armchair positioned next to a table meticulously set for tea. He begins the meticulous process of pouring tea into elegant china cups before clasping his hands gently in his lap. 

Abruptly, the film cuts to the long hallway within the confines of Mickey's parents' apartment. At the end of the hallway, Mickey's mother stands dramatically in front of a bureau, screaming at the top of her lungs while clutching her heart. Mickey's father, in contrast, appears calmly, walking into view carrying a teacup in one hand and a candy dish in the other. He strides purposefully past Mickey, making his way into the kitchen. As he holds the dirty dishes, Mickey's father glances over at his son. He then exits offscreen once more, heading to the kitchen sink. Upon his return, Mickey's father walks out of the kitchen and strides past his son, venturing into the living room. Meanwhile, Mickey stops in front of the bathroom door at the opposite end of the hallway, beginning to pound on it with urgency. Mickey's father reappears, now carrying a plate of hors d'oeuvres along with an empty glass, making his way toward the kitchen. He halts momentarily, casting a look down the hallway at Mickey, who is now struggling earnestly to open the stubbornly locked bathroom door.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
The two sisters, moving in unison yet with Hannah slightly advancing ahead, start to make their way away from the colorful clothing rack they had been perusing. As they progress further, Holly pauses for a brief moment, casting a thoughtful and reflective glance toward her sister. They continue on their walk, keeping up their steady sisterly pace. Holly takes another lingering look at her sister, pondering deeply for a moment. Meanwhile, a female customer, who had previously approached the table with curiosity, is busy browsing through the garments on the rack located near Hannah and suddenly lifts her gaze in reaction. This customer then makes the decision to walk away, her interest shifting. She strolls past Holly, briefly casting her eyes on a different rack of clothes that is positioned beneath the table. Her journey continues onward as she walks offscreen toward a nearby rack, while the camera's focus remains fixed on Holly. With a chuckle escaping her lips, Holly begins to sift through the selection of vibrant scarves adorning the table.

In the grand theater, a group comprising several theater executives, including the influential producer, the creative director, and two diligent assistants, is seated in a closely-knit cluster amidst the many empty audience seats. They are engaged in lively conversation, but soon they collectively look up, directing their attention towards Holly, who is performing out of sight, auditioning earnestly on the stage. As the film transitions from the vast audience to the illuminated stage, Holly is revealed to be standing there, her hands elegantly clasped in front of her as she continues to sing her heart out with passion. A large group of other aspiring performers can be observed waiting patiently in the background behind her, creating an atmosphere filled with hopeful anticipation. The camera's angle changes from Holly back to the executives seated in the audience. Once the camera reaches them, they are now animatedly chattering among themselves, seemingly having already forgotten about Holly amidst the excitement of their conversation.

The scene shifts to a bustling street where an impressive theater marquee is visible. Holly, accompanied by April, walks along the street, moving closer and closer to the ever-focusful camera as they engage in a casual yet meaningful conversation. A hint of sadness briefly crosses Holly's face as she diverts her gaze, her expression marked by a slow and somber shake of her head. The film then transitions smoothly to the serene interior of Father Flynn's rectory office. The Catholic priest stands calmly, gazing thoughtfully out of a simply adorned stained-glass window before turning his attention to someone offscreen, Mickey. The camera angle adjusts, gradually revealing Mickey, who is positioned with his back to the camera, sitting patiently in a chair facing Father Flynn's imposing desk. The scene transitions gracefully to capture Mickey's face, and then the camera reverts back to Father Flynn, who moves over to a nearby, comfortable leather armchair positioned next to a table meticulously set for an elegant tea. He begins the meticulous process of pouring tea into elegant china cups before clasping his hands gently in his lap, waiting.

Abruptly, the film cuts to the elongated hallway within the warmly adorned confines of Mickey's parents' apartment. At the far end of the hallway, Mickey's mother stands dramatically in front of a bureau, screaming at the top of her lungs, her voice echoing, while clutching her heart with emotion. Mickey's father, in marked contrast, appears calm and composed, walking into view carrying a delicate teacup in one hand and a decorative candy dish in the other. He strides purposefully past Mickey, making his way intently into the kitchen. As he holds the dirty dishes, Mickey's father glances over momentarily at his son. He then exits offscreen once more, heading diligently to the kitchen sink. Upon his return, Mickey's father walks out of the kitchen and strides past his son once again, venturing thoughtfully into the inviting living room. Meanwhile, Mickey stops in front of the bathroom door at the opposite end of the hallway, beginning to pound on it with growing urgency. Mickey's father reappears, now carrying a plate of hors d'oeuvres along with an empty glass, making his way steadily toward the kitchen. He halts briefly, casting a look down the hallway at Mickey, who is now struggling earnestly to open the stubbornly locked bathroom door, his efforts filled with determination.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As the two sisters move away from the rack, Hannah slightly ahead in their stride, Holly momentarily hesitates, casting a glance at her sister before they proceed together. Holly allows her gaze to linger on her sister momentarily. Nearby, a female customer approaches the table, casually browsing through the rack of clothes close to Hannah, and her attention is briefly captured as she looks up and reacts to their movement. She quietly steps away from the table, passing by Holly, and momentarily shifts her focus to a different rack of clothes positioned beneath the table before she continues onward, walking offscreen towards a nearby rack, while the camera keeps Holly in its sights. Holly emits a light chuckle and begins to sift through the assortment of scarves spread out on the table. Meanwhile, a group of theater executives, comprising the producer, the director, and two assistants, gathers in a cluster within the empty audience seating, engaged in conversation. Their attention is eventually diverted as they look up towards the offscreen Holly, who is actively auditioning on the stage. The scene transitions from the audience to the stage where Holly, with her hands clasped together in front of her, continues to deliver her song, with a large group of other hopeful auditionees visible in the background. The camera shifts focus back to the executives in the audience, now engaged in conversation among themselves, having seemingly forgotten about Holly. As the film progresses, the theater marquee becomes visible on the bustling street as Holly and April walk down the street, moving towards the camera, drawing nearer as they engage in conversation. Holly's demeanor shifts as she looks aside with a somber expression, gently shaking her head. The scene then transitions abruptly to Father Flynn's rectory office, where the Catholic priest stands gazing out of a simple stained-glass window before turning his attention to Mickey, who is offscreen. The camera pans back to reveal Mickey, seated with his back to the camera, facing Father Flynn's desk. The film cuts to a close-up of Mickey's face before returning focus to Father Flynn, who moves over to a leather armchair situated next to a table that is elegantly set for tea. As he begins pouring tea into delicate china cups, Father Flynn clasps his hands together in his lap. Suddenly, the scene shifts to a long hallway in Mickey's parents' apartment, where his mother stands dramatically in front of a bureau at the hallway's end, her voice raised in a scream as she dramatically clutches her heart. Mickey's father enters the frame, carrying a teacup and a candy dish, and confidently strides past Mickey heading towards the kitchen. As he passes, he glances at his son while holding the dirty dishes, then exits offscreen to the kitchen sink. After attending to the dishes, Mickey's father reemerges from the kitchen, traversing past his son once more toward the living room. Meanwhile, Mickey halts at the bathroom door situated at the opposite end of the hallway and begins to pound on it. His father reappears, this time carrying a plate of hors d'oeuvres and an empty glass as he walks back towards the kitchen, momentarily pausing to cast a look down the hallway at Mickey, who is now grappling with the locked bathroom door.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description:
The two sisters walk away from the rack, with Hannah slightly ahead. Holly pauses, observing her sister before they both continue. A female customer, who was browsing near Hannah, reacts and moves offscreen after briefly glancing at a different rack. Holly chuckles and starts browsing through the scarves on the table. Meanwhile, theater executives, including the producer, director, and two assistants, sit in an empty audience watching Holly, who is auditioning on stage with other hopefuls in the background. While she sings with her hands clasped, the executives chatter among themselves, diverting their attention from her. The scene shifts to a busy street where Holly and April walk toward the camera, talking. Holly looks away sadly and shakes her head.

The film transitions to Father Flynn's rectory office where the priest glances out a stained-glass window before turning to an offscreen Mickey. The camera reveals Mickey sitting in front of Father Flynn's desk. Father Flynn then walks to a leather armchair, pours tea into china cups, and clasps his hands. Suddenly, the scene cuts to a long hallway in Mickey's parents' apartment. Mickey's mother stands at the hallway's end, dramatically screaming and clutching her heart. His father enters, carrying a teacup and a candy dish, strides past Mickey towards the kitchen, then returns carrying hors d'oeuvres and an empty glass. He pauses to watch Mickey struggle to open the bathroom door.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The two sisters walk away from the rack, Hannah slightly in the lead, sensing an opportunity in this bustling fashion boutique known for its eclectic collection. Holly pauses, looking at her sister, as if weighing the choices before them. They continue to walk. Holly looks at her sister for a beat, perhaps considering the day's events. A female customer, who'd come over to the table, browsing through the rack of clothes near Hannah, looks up, reacting to the lively atmosphere of the store. She walks away, lost in thought about her next purchase. She walks past Holly and briefly looks at a different rack of clothes beneath the table, where vintage items are often hidden treasures. She walks offscreen to a nearby rack; the camera remains focused on Holly. Holly chuckles and begins to look through the scarves on the table, which are imported from Italy, each telling its own story through its pattern and fabric. A group of theater executives, including the producer, the director, and two assistants, sit in a cluster in the empty audience, talking about the upcoming production's potential; they look up at the offscreen Holly, who is auditioning on the stage for a role in a highly anticipated play. The film moves from the audience to the stage where Holly, her hands clasped in front of her, continues to sing her song, a soulful rendition that echoes the themes of hope and longing. A large group of other hopefuls are seen in the background behind her, all competing for the same chance at stardom. The camera moves from Holly back to the executives in the audience. The camera has reached the executives in the audience. They are now chattering among themselves, Holly forgotten for the moment as they deliberate over casting decisions. A theater marquee can be seen on the busy street as Holly and April walk down the street towards the camera, moving closer and closer as they talk about their dreams and aspirations. Holly looks away sadly; she shakes her head, feeling the weight of uncertainty. The film cuts to Father Flynn's rectory office, a serene space filled with books and religious artifacts. The Catholic priest looks out a simple stained-glass window, then turns to an offscreen Mickey, who is seeking guidance. The camera moves back to reveal Mickey, his back to the camera, sitting in front of Father Flynn's desk, a symbol of authority and empathy. The movie cuts to Mickey's face, showing his anxiety. The camera cuts back to Father Flynn, who walks over to a leather armchair next to a table set for tea, a ritual of comfort and conversation. He begins to pour the tea into china cups, which have been in the parish for generations. Father Flynn clasps his hands in his lap, contemplating the situation. The film abruptly cuts to the long hallway in Mickey's parents' apartment, a narrow passage that seems to contain countless family memories. Mickey's mother stands in front of this bureau at the hallway's end, screaming at the top of her lungs, holding her heart dramatically as if she is auditioning for an opera. His father walks into view, carrying a teacup and a candy dish, remnants of their recent family gathering. He strides past Mickey towards the kitchen. Holding the dirty dishes in his hand, Mickey's father looks at his son, communicating without words. Mickey's father walks offscreen again, to the kitchen sink, where he begins to wash away the stress of the day. Mickey's father walks out of the kitchen, past his son, to the living room, perhaps seeking a moment's peace. Mickey stops at the bathroom door at the other end of the hallway. He starts to pound it, hoping to be heard. Mickey's father comes back on screen; he's carrying a plate of hors d'oeuvres and an empty glass towards the kitchen, tasks that never cease in a bustling household. He stops and looks down the hall at Mickey, who's now struggling to open the bathroom door, a minor setback in their chaotic day.

In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. The film shifts from the audience to the stage where Holly, her hands resting in front of her, proceeds to recite her song. A large group of other hopefuls are visible in the background behind her. Holly glances away sadly; she shrugs her shoulders. The film cuts to Father Flynn's rectory office. The Catholic priest gazes out a plain stained-glass window, then pivots to an offscreen Mickey. The camera shifts back to reveal Mickey, his back to the camera, lounging in front of Father Flynn's desk. The movie shifts to Mickey's face. The camera shifts back to Father Flynn, who strides over to a leather armchair next to a table arranged for tea. He proceeds to brew the tea into china cups. Father Flynn entwines his fingers in his lap. The film suddenly cuts to the long hallway in Mickey's parents' apartment. Mickey's mother stands in front of this bureau at the hallway's end, shouting at the top of her lungs, clutching her heart dramatically. His father strides into view, balancing a teacup and a candy dish. He marches past Mickey towards the kitchen. Balancing the dirty dishes in his hand, Mickey's father peers at his son. Mickey's father strides offscreen again, to the kitchen sink. Mickey's father marches out of the kitchen, past his son, to the living room. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption

Maple glances at her penguin for a moment. A male astronaut, who'd floated over to the bookshelf, browsing through the chandelier of shoes near Ginger, gazes up, responding. He glides away. He glides past Maple and briefly examines a different chandelier of shoes beneath the bookshelf. He glides offscreen to a nearby chandelier; the lens remains focused on Maple. Maple giggles and starts to sift through the blankets on the bookshelf. A bunch of fashion critics, including the composer, the painter, and two librarians, huddle in a swarm in the vacant garden, whispering; they glance up at the offscreen Maple, who is juggling on the dock. The documentary shifts from the garden to the dock where Maple, her feet stomped on the ground, keeps juggling her apples. A small fleet of other spectators are spotted in the backdrop behind her. The lens shifts from Maple back to the critics in the garden. The lens has reached the critics in the garden. They are now yammering among themselves, Maple overlooked. A market gazebo can be seen on the bustling beach as Maple and August run across the beach towards the lens, sprinting closer and closer as they chatter. Maple gazes away cheerfully; she nods her head. The documentary switches to Sister June's library lounge. The Buddhist nun gazes out a grand stone window, then spins to an offscreen Jerry. The lens shifts back to uncover Jerry, his front to the lens, standing behind Sister June's shelf. The documentary switches to Jerry's hand. The lens switches back to Sister June, who skips over to a steel rocking chair next to a shelf set for soup. She starts to sip the soup from ceramic bowls. Sister June stomps her eyes on her lap. The documentary suddenly switches to the narrow corridor in Jerry's neighbor's warehouse. Jerry's cousin dances in front of this wardrobe at the corridor's edge, laughing at the top of her voice, clutching her hat wildly. His uncle hops into sight, tossing a soup bowl and a cookie jar. He veers past Jerry towards the balcony. Balancing the clean jars in his hand, Jerry's uncle gazes at his cousin. Jerry's uncle hops offscreen again, to the balcony railing. Jerry's uncle hops out of the balcony, past his cousin, to the garage. Jerry sprints at the pantry drawer at the opposite side of the corridor. He stops to nudge it. Jerry's uncle skates back on display; he's hauling a jar of crêpes and a full vase towards the balcony. He pauses and gazes up the corridor at Jerry, who's now tumbling to close the pantry drawer.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Hannah and Holly, two sisters, walk away from a rack, with Hannah slightly ahead. Holly pauses, watching her sister, then chuckles and browses a table of scarves. Nearby, a female customer glances around before leaving. A group of theater executives, including a producer and director, are seated, observing Holly audition on stage among other hopefuls. The camera shifts back to the executives, now lost in conversation. Holly and another woman, April, are later seen walking past a theater marquee, with Holly appearing saddened. In a different scene, Father Flynn, a Catholic priest, is in his rectory office, pouring tea and talking to Mickey, whose back is to the camera. The film shifts again to Mickey's parents' apartment, where his mother dramatically screams, while his father moves through the apartment with dishes in hand. Mickey pounds on a bathroom door in frustration, while his father watches before continuing past him.

test_cases.name: Jumble Segments Order

to a leather armchair next to a table set for tea Mickey stops at the bathroom door at the other end of the hallway Holly forgotten Mickey's father comes back on screen The movie cuts to Mickey's face assistants sit in a cluster in the empty audience talking The film abruptly cuts to the long hallway in Mickey's parents' apartment sadly she shakes her head they look up at the offscreen Holly who is auditioning on the stage The camera moves back to reveal Mickey his back to the camera sitting in front of Father Flynn's desk Mickey's father walks offscreen again to the kitchen sink Mickey's father walks out of the kitchen past his son to the living room He strides past Mickey towards the kitchen The film moves from the audience to the stage where Holly her hands clasped in front of her continues to sing her song The Catholic priest looks out a simple stainedglass window then turns to an offscreen Mickey Holly looks away Father Flynn clasps his hands in his lap He starts to pound it Mickey's mother stands in front of this bureau at the hallway's end screaming at the top of her lungs holding her heart dramatically A theater marquee can be seen on the busy street as Holly and April slightly in the lead She walks past Holly and briefly looks at a different rack of clothes beneath the table he is carrying a plate of hors d'oeuvres and an empty glass towards the kitchen
